Award.AwardTitle: Intergratable Quantum Field Theories:New Methods And Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
There is large and expanding array of problems in fundamental physics (ranging from sub-nuclear structure of matter through astrophysics and cosmology) which deal with systems whose theoretical description involves continuously many variables with strong interconnection between them. Quantum field theory is a unifying mathematical language for such systems. Appropriately, this language is difficult, and in general its "grammatical rules" are not even yet established. In this situation, any instances, or "models", of quantum field theory whose equations can be worked out all the way through are especially valuable. Such models are known as "integrable quantum field theories". Mainly, they serve as the testing ground for verification and development of ideas and mathematical methods, but remarkably many integrable "models" directly apply to theoretical understanding of properties of complex materials. That is why today the integrable quantum field theories constitute one of the most important and actively developed area of mathematical physics. Moreover, since the discovery of "gauge/string duality" and the role of integrability in this relation, this field of research has found itself at the cutting edge of theoretical high-energy physics. Unfortunately, the integrable models emerging in this context still resist full solution. This research project proposes further development of integrable quantum field theories, with emphasis on the so-called integrable sigma models. This is exactly the general class of models which emerge in the context of the gauge/string duality. Also, similar models are believed to provide theoretical understanding of particularly complicated disordered systems in physics of materials. It is proposed to develop a certain new class of integrable sigma-models, with novel mathematical structure, and find full solutions. This is an intermediate step in the approach to the systems of direct application in the gauge/string dualities. Interestingly, mathematical methods developed for integrable quantum field theories turn out to have broader significance in mathematical physics, and often help to investigate a wider class of non-integrable systems. This area will be explored as well.

The activity consists of three projects. (1) Analysis of a new class of integrable sigma models whose target spaces are deformed group manifolds. With the most general known deformations, quantum integrability of such models require significant modifications of standard tools such as the Lax representations, the Yang-Baxter algebras, and Baxter's Q operators and their relations. The project's goal is to develop all such modifications, and use that as the basis for finding full solutions. The key to our approach will be the so-called ODE/IQFT correspondence, the new mathematical tool of integrable quantum field theories ("IQFT side") which allows to "encode" its algebraic structures into a system of ordinary differential equations ("ODE" side). This project lays in the mainstream of the current research in mathematical physics; its significance is in the relation to the gauge/string dualities, and possibly to physics of disordered systems. The other two parts the research is to explore applications of the methods of integrability in non-integrable systems. (2) The relation between the 't Hooft's equation in 1+1 QCD and the Baxter's T-Q equation will be used to analyze the meson decays and scattering amplitudes in the large-N expansion, with the ultimate goal of gaining universal tools for analysis of decays and amplitudes in generic 1+1 systems with confining interactions, which are very common in condensed matter physics. (3) The third part addresses possibility of emergence of near-integrable subsystems in otherwise non-integrable quantum field theories, the possibility which was not previously explored.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Quantum field theory, i.e., quantum mechanics of systems with continuously many constituents, remains among the most advanced tool of theoretical physics. It has shown its power in the treatment of the most challenging problems in the theoretical description of nature, such as understanding the microscopic structure of matter beyond the Standard Model, or properties of complex condensed matter systems. A class of two dimensional - with one space and one time dimension - quantum field theories, the so-called sigma models, are at the heart of the modern approaches to fundamental interactions: the string theories and gauge/string dualities. However, precise mathematical control of these theories is difficult. Fortunately, there is an important family of integrable quantum field theories for which, in virtue of large hidden symmetries, an exact treatment is possible, and many of the  relevant sigma models as well as models of condensed matter physics belong to this class. Despite their special properties, solving integrable theories is often a challenging problem. Lately, a new powerful method known as the ODE/IQFT correspondence was developed which allows one to relate complex mathematical structures behind Integrable Quantum Field Theories (IQFT) to the much simpler mathematics of Ordinary Differential Equations (ODE). This project's objectives were to advance the ODE/IQFT correspondence in a number of ways, to apply the approach to specific sigma models and models of condensed matter physics for exploring physical properties, and to develop a more general understanding of integrable theories by charting the space of such theories in geometric terms.

The most important outcomes of the project are:

(1) The development of the ODE/IQFT correspondence for an important class of sigma models - the so-called 2D and 3D sausage models, as well as the related Bukhvostov-Lipatov model - and finding solutions of these models, with potential applications to gauge/string dualities.

(2) The development of the ODE/IQFT approach to calculations in quantum Kondo systems, i.e., the systems consisting of a sea of Fermi excitations interacting with an impurity spin. Of much practical interest are the so-called quantum quenches, the processes in which the interaction strength suddenly changes. Adopting the ODE/IQFT correspondence to such systems allowed for the first time exact calculation of the overlap of the ground states of systems with different spin interactions, and the investigation of its physical properties.

(3) Exact calculations of the asymptotic form of separated spin correlations in integrable spin chains such as the XXZ chain, thus demonstrating the power of methods of IQFT in treating important systems of condensed matter.

(4) The development of the geometric approach to the space of IQFT. Specifically, determining all infinitesimal deformations of a given IQFT which preserve its integrable symmetry structure, and relating such deformations to special deformations of the associated quantum particle scattering amplitudes. Discovering a universal deformation of a generic quantum field theory - the "T-Tbar flow" - which admits an exact solution for some physical quantities such as the quantum energy levels at finite size, and has applications in holographic dualities and QCD string models.

 

Development of efficient theoretical methods for the description of complex natural phenomena is an outstanding challenge in physics. The project advances this objective by developing the ODE/IQFT correspondence in integrable sigma models as well as other systems, and by applying geometric ideas to the space consisting of all IQFT, including the discovery of the "T-Tbar" deformations. These developments determine the intellectual merit of the project. Since quantum field theory is regarded as a suitable device for addressing such problems, the results of this project would have a significant impact on the theoretical approach to the Natural Sciences and on culture in general. The completed research has contributed to the training and professional development of two graduate students, and has led to a course of lectures for student training in IQFT.
